block.p: Choice dry ros'es, as light as summer's air currents, are garden parties in a bottle. Their watercolor palettes -- pink, cherry, coral, salmon -- and delicate flavors lift the spirit and tickle the appetite. Today, the breed, defamed by white zinfandel, is redeemed by Spanish rosado.

Navarra, in the north, has become synonymous with stylish rosado, like the '99 Vega Sindoa from Bodegas Nekeas. A sweet grenache-cabernet bouquet yields to a dry, tangy collage of miniaturized fruity flavors. Pour the wine with flounder, chicken, veal, ham or salmon.

Navarra, in the north, has become synonymous with stylish rosado, like the '99 Vega Sindoa from Bodegas Nekeas. A sweet grenache-cabernet bouquet yields to a dry, tangy collage of miniaturized fruity flavors. Pour the wine with flounder, chicken, veal, ham or salmon.

Francophiles may relish the '99 Chateau Routas Rouvi'ere ros'e, an almost austere grenache-syrah-cinsault blend that alluringly whispers the Provencal accents of its obscure Coteaux Varois appellation.
The '99 Wolffer dry ros'e from the fashionable Sagpond Vineyards in Sagaponack, on the South Fork of Long Island, is a tailgate-picnic favorite at the Hamptons Classic horse show.
Drink these wines young; if you ice them long, it's vinicide. Pour them marginally cool, swish them aerobically in your mouth for fully 45 seconds and watch them become Salomes.
In Manhattan, Vega Sindoa is $7 at Baccus, 1375 First Avenue (74th Street), and $8 at Grande Harvest, opposite Track 17 in Grand Central Terminal.
The Routas costs $10 at Manley's, 35 Eighth Avenue (12th Street) and $10 at Direct Cellars.com, 160 Chambers Street (Greenwich Street).
The Wolffer is $9 at Acker Merrall & Condit, 160 West 72d Street (Broadway), and $10 at the Windsor Wine Shop, 474 Third Avenue (33d Street).
